text: [Music]
hi everyone
Anthony Fantino here the Internet's
busiest music nerd trying out a new
camera angle let me know what you think
about it leave comment the Internet's
most visibly sweaty music nerd and it's
time for you review the band Shabab ah
easily the most badass band name I've
ever said on this channel Shiva
thank you you you you this band's name
comes from Mayan folklore and translates
roughly into place of fear which was
supposed to be inhabited by about 12
gods who lord it over various causes of
human suffering death sickness
starvation and more and to make things
even more morbid this band's new LP
their first album for the southern Lorde
label has the title hasta la muerte
which is to the death in Spanish
these guys are aggressive as hell
they're brutal as hell and they just
deliver this building crumbling
heaviness on track after track their
earlier material did have a really
aggressive energy but I think they
really went above and beyond on this new
LP really kind of bringing that hardcore
punk ferocity with a sludge metal
heaviness with the brand of low end that
is very deserving of a spot in the
southern Lord discography now southern
lord has been carrying a lot of sludgy
hardcore punk hybrids I have reviewed a
handful of them a few of my most recent
favorites have been black breath as well
as the band males and Taylor young from
nails Ashley does production on this LP
and Greg Anderson of Sun comes in and
contributes droney heavy loud guitars on
a couple tracks too and the special
attention that these guys have gotten
this LP is really paid off because this
album is so loud you cannot turn it down
there are only two speeds at which
you can go deaf to this LP fast and sort
of fast so yes these guys are incredibly
brutal and this extra attention that I
just mentioned has brought a bit of
detail character and finesse to the very
blood-thirsty
sound you do get this very heavy low-end
sludge and doom Rivage mixed with that
Punk speed but these guys also have the
tendency to embark on these massive
metalcore and beat down hardcore style
breakdowns as well which I kind of have
a love/hate relationship with I'm from
Connecticut where we had a pretty
thriving hardcore and in metalcore scene
about ten years ago bands like hatebreed
were pretty much spearheading that sound
for the area and if you couldn't see
Hatebreed live there were definitely a
number of local acts who were kind of
emulating their sound so when I was a
teenager I was kind of around people
that listened to that I liked it too
however when I got older I kind of
realized how shallow and redundant those
genres can be but if you are you know
interested in them curious I would
definitely recommend Hatebreed or terror
terror
so again should ball but heavenly hands
don't do that so the band definitely has
that style of aggression and I find a
lot of their tracks on this LP to be
pretty dynamic the aggression
complements the experimentation and vice
versa
you have the drones you have the long
strung out dumi riffs and some noise as
well on here that kind of keeps things
very dark and very tortured but those
very fast and hard and and aggressive
riffs and breakdowns keep things from
getting too long-winded too boring too
drawn-out this LP opens up with a very
dark drones and nice rich textures and
some very caveman like prehistoric drums
cavernous reverb on them and Greg
Anderson isn't even on this track it's
nice to know that this band can kind of
create those sounds pretty well on their
own really kind of create a massive
atmosphere but right after this short
atmospheric intro they bust right into
the quickness with kind of a variation
on a DB and then from there on in on the
track it is just mosh mosh mosh mosh
mosh the bass is so heavy they're not
humble when it comes to the rumble
especially when they lay on those
breakdown riffs and back them up with
some harmonious guitar leads it's kind
of a rough quality to them that reminds
me a lot of that freaking dyzma album
that I liked so much last year after
that the track laid to rest has a really
nice mosh worthy groove and so does the
song burn I mean just really great riffs
adrenaline pumping my only issue with
the handful of tracks on the first half
of this LP even though they do come out
swinging there are some spots that do
feel a little you know inconspicuous hey
I know this is really heavy and massive
but I could kind of hear this riff or
just something like it just about
anywhere the second half on here I
thought was way more experimental and
sound rich the track flood is the first
one that Greg Anderson appears on and it
escalates just
statically it starts off really loud and
just he and cheb Alba work on making the
sound one shade louder as it progresses
and I'm just like man how much louder
can they make it oh wow it's louder now
how much louder can they make it oh man
it's louder now how much louder can they
make it the title track has a really
long moody intro and I think it's catchy
a song on the album has a really
memorable hook and the entirety of the
lyrics are in Spanish the song ma la
mujer is a track that was a little
off-putting as a female vocalist on it
whose voice is manipulated with effects
in a way that I didn't really care for
though it was a nice addition to the
album kind of broke things up brought
some variation and the lyrics which are
in English are very much about
heartbreak and just suffering and in
pain in relation to love or the lack of
it coming from someone you want it from
and the last two tracks on here are the
longest on the album Greg Anderson is on
the last one and they are droney
and riffey odyssey's really two of the
more interesting spots on the album I
thought I would love to see Chabal be'
experiment with this more even blend of
this hardcore and drone and doom sound
on their next LP for sure like I said
with this LP there are some
inconspicuous spots if you're familiar
with this genre some things are just
gonna feel maybe a little too familiar
for you and the vocals which are really
abrasive and really in your face just
engulfing the microphone with volume and
just thrown yet I wish they varied up a
little bit more but there's enough
change to them in the background vocals
throughout this LP to you know not make
them feel annoyingly one-sided and
Shabab but definitely does a great job
of bringing some some amazing aggression
together with it with another level of
heaviness I'm feeling a light too decent
eight on this thing what did you guys
think of this if you've given it a
listen
did you love it did you hate it why and
what do you think I should review
next remember the good comment the great
rate but only the strong subscribed
Anthony Fantino cheb Alba
I said I'm where day forever
